description: Occurs when the loop iterates one time too few or too many, often due to incorrect use of <=, <, >= or > operators.
The loop terminates too early or too late because of an incorrect boundary condition or logic.
The code fails to handle edge cases like empty input, large values, or single-element arrays.
The function returns a value that does not match the expected output due to incorrect logic or data handling.
Using == instead of >=, or < instead of <=, which leads to logical errors in conditionals or loops.
Choosing a wrong or suboptimal data structure, like using a list instead of a set, leading to incorrect behavior or poor performance.
Variables are initialized with incorrect default values, leading to unintended results or failure to accumulate data properly.
The loop never terminates due to incorrect condition or missing update to loop variables.
Accessing an array or list index that does not exist, which may crash the program or yield incorrect values.
A recursive function does not correctly handle its base case, leading to stack overflow or incorrect results.
